abstract.text: A crisis like the COVID-19 outbreak is a major public health event that causes 75 significant uncertainty and isolation. The negative impact may be even greater among 76 pregnant women who have increased stress due to concerns for their fetus.

Key findings 78 An increase in the prevalence of depressive and anxiety symptoms were found after 79 the announcement of COVID-19 human-to-human transmission. Pregnant women 80 also reported significantly more self-harm thoughts. Women at increased risk for 81 depression post-crisis announcement included those who were primiparous, <35 years 82 of age, pre-pregnancy underweight, employed full-time, middle income, had a per 83 capita living area of ≥20 m 2 , and had decreased physical activity.
What does this add to what is known?
Major public health emergencies may increase the depressive and anxiety levels in the 86 pregnant women.

88 Background: On January 20, 2020, a new coronavirus epidemic with 89 "human-to-human" transmission was officially announced by the Chinese government, 90 which caused significant public panic in China. Pregnant women may be particularly 91 vulnerable and in special need for preventative mental health strategies. Thus far, no 92 reports exist to investigate the mental health response of pregnant women to the 93 COVID-19 outbreak.

94 Objective: The aim of the present study is to examine the impact of COVID-19 95 outbreak on the prevalence of depressive and anxiety symptoms and the 96 corresponding risk factors among pregnant women across China. 97 Study Design: A multi-center cross-sectional study was initiated in early December 98 2019 to identify mental health concerns in pregnancy using the Edinburgh Postnatal 99 Depression Scale (EPDS). This study provided a unique opportunity to compare the 100 mental status of pregnant women before and after the announcement of the 101 COVID-19 epidemic. A total of 4124 pregnant women during their third trimester 102 from 25 hospitals in 10 provinces across China were examined in this cross-sectional 103 study from January 1 to February 9, 2020. Of these women, 1285 were assessed after 104 January 20, 2020 when the coronavirus epidemic was publically announced and 2839 105 were assessed before this pivotal time point. The internationally recommended EPDS 106 was used to assess maternal depression and anxiety symptoms. Prevalence rates and 107 risk factors were compared between the pre and post study groups.

108 Results: Pregnant women assessed after the declaration of COVID-19 epidemic had 109 significantly higher rates of depressive symptoms (26.0% vs 29.6%, P=0.02) than 110 women assess pre-epidemic announcement. These women were also more likely to 111 endorse thoughts of self-harm (P=0.005). The depressive rates were positively 112 associated with the number of newly-confirmed COVID-19 cases (P=0.003), 113 suspected infections (P=0.004), and death cases per day (P=0.001). Pregnant women 114 who were underweight pre-pregnancy, primiparous, < 35 years old, employed 115 full-time, middle income, and had appropriate living space were at increased risk to 116 develop depressive and anxiety symptoms during the outbreak.

117 Conclusion: Major life-threatening public health events such as the COVID-19 118 outbreak may increase the risk for mental illness among pregnant women including 119 thoughts of self-harm. Strategies targeting maternal stress and isolation such as 120 effective risk communication and the provision of psychological first aid may be 121 particularly useful to prevent negative outcomes for women and their fetuses.

body_text.text: Human-to-human transmission of COVID-19 was first confirmed and reported by 162 Chinese government on January 20, 2020. In early December 2019 before the 163 COVID-19 outbreak, our team initiated a multi-center cross-sectional study to 164 identify mental health concerns in pregnancy using the Edinburgh Postnatal 165 Depression Scale (EPDS). This study provided a unique opportunity to compare the 166 mental status of pregnant women before and after the announcement of the 167 COVID-19 epidemic. In order to examine the effect of a major public health 168 emergency on the mental health of pregnant women, data from January 1 to February 169 9, 2020 were obtained from the Perinatal and Postpartum Depression Information 170 Collection System we built. For this current study, all participants were categorized 171 into two groups based on whether human-to-human transmission of COVID-19 had 172 been reported when the study questionnaire was completed (group 1: before the 173 declaration of human-to-human transmission; group 2: after the declaration). placental previa and exercise. We also consider investigation sites, history of diseases, 227 use of assisted reproductive technology (ART) and twins pregnancy as potential 228 confounders, but adjustment for these variables did not change the results and 229 therefore we did not include them in the final models. We did not use imputing data 230 analyses due to no missing data. (Table 1 ). Due to the small proportion of 237 women with a history of anxiety or depression (<1%), we did not exclude them in the 238 following analyses.

Depressive and Anxiety Symptoms and COVID-19. We found that women in 240 group 2 had higher mean EPDS scores (mean ± SD: 7.7 ± 4.4 vs. 7.4 ± 4.3) and 241 anxiety subscale scores (mean ± SD: 3.4 ± 1.7 vs. 3.2 ± 1.7) than those in group 1. (Table 2) . This study examined the relationship between a major life-threatening public health 283 event and maternal mental health where there is increased stress and fear due to the 284 additional concern for an unborn fetus. After the declaration of human-to-human 285 transmission of the COVID-19 by the Chinese government on January 20, 2020, 286 global concern and uncertainty increased dramatically. A clinically significant rise in 287 the prevalence of depressive symptoms was found among pregnant women increasing 288 from 26% before January 20 to 34.2% between February 5 to 9, 2020. A significant 289 increase in anxiety symptoms was also found. The outbreak of COVID-19 may 290 contribute to a significant increase in mild depressive symptoms instead of severe 291 symptoms, as we found that the percentage of women with EPDS scores between 10 292 and 12 was higher after the COVID-19 epidemic declaration (data not shown).

Not surprising, the prevalence of depressive symptoms increased as the number 294 of death and newly-diagnosed cases also increased. Due to the sudden outbreak, the 295 features of the COVID-19 virus and symptoms remained unknown for weeks causing 296 heightened fear overall and concern for vertical transmission from mother to fetus 297 among pregnant women. Rapid reporting though news and social media eliminated 298 the regional differences such that increased rates of depressive symptoms was found 299 among pregnant women in the 10 participating provinces independent of the number 300 of cases found locally.

FIGREF0.text: , China was reported to the Chinese health authorities starting on 128 December 8, 2019. 1 The pathogenic agent was identified as a 2019 novel 129 coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) and the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the 130 virus outbreak a public health emergency of international concern. 2 At the beginning 131 of the outbreak, much remained unknown except that it was transmitted by direct 132 exposure at a local animal market. 3 Person-to-person transmission of the COVID-19 133 was revealed to the Chinese public by the government on January 20, 2020 and that 134 asymptomatic individuals were potential sources of infection. 4,5 The number of 135 identified cases continued to increase as did the public panic and flow of 136 misinformation. 137 To date, epidemiological data on the mental health problems of the general 138 population during the COVID-19 outbreak has not been available and how to best 139 respond to challenges during the outbreak remains unknown. Those in quarantine 140 often experience boredom, loneliness, and anger and on social media the virus has 141 been repeatedly described as a killer virus, perpetuating a sense of danger and 142 uncertainty among the public. In the early phase of the 2003 SARS outbreak, a range 143 of psychiatric morbidities, including persistent depression, anxiety, panic attacks, 144 psychotic symptoms, and even suicidality, were reported. 6,7 Mandatory contact tracing 145 and 14 days quarantine, which form part of the public health responses to the 146 COVID-19 outbreak, increased anxiety, feelings of isolation and stigma. 6,7 147 One particularly vulnerable group during a viral outbreak may be pregnant 148 women. Mental health disorders are a common cause of morbidity during pregnancy 149 with approximately 12% of women experiencing depression and up to 22% 150 experiencing high levels of anxiety in late pregnancy. 8,9 Pregnant women are more 151 vulnerable to infections due to their naturally suppressed immune system and are 152 generally considered at increased risk for severe complications. 10 Moreover, pregnant 153 women may be further vulnerable to anxiety due to increased concern about vertical 154 transmission to their fetus. To date, the mental health response of pregnant women to 155 the COVID-19 outbreak has not been investigated. The aim of the present study is to 156 examine the prevalence of depression and anxiety after COVID-19 outbreak and the 157 corresponding risk factors.

FIGREF3.text: cross-sectional study was performed in 25 public hospitals from 10 182 provinces across China, covering the East, the Middle, the Northwest, the Northeast 183 and South. Pregnant women in their third trimester of pregnancy were invited to 184 complete a study questionnaire by a trained research assistant during their regular 185 obstetric clinic visit. Questions pertained to sociodemographic characteristics, 186 lifestyles, reproductive history, history of mental health problems, current depressive 187 symptoms, marital and family support, pregnancy complications (threatened abortion, 188 gestational diabetes mellitus, hypertensive disorder, placental previa, intrahepatic 189 cholestasis of pregnancy, oligohydramnios and intrauterine growth restriction).

FIGREF4.text: were measured by EPDS, the most frequently used and 192 internationally recommended screening measure for perinatal depression.11,12 EPDS   193    was used to evaluate feelings in the last 7 days with a cut-off score of 10 or higher 194 recommended to detect possible depression during community-based screening.13,14  In 195 this study, a cut-off score of 10 or higher was used to analyze group differences in 196 depression as this lower cut-off is recommended for Asian population. 12 In addition to 197 depression, the EPDS may be used to assess anxiety symptoms. The accumulative198 score from the items 3, 4 and 5 in EPDS (EPDS-3A) represent the anxiety 199 dimension. 15,16 200 Statistical analysis 201 All analyses were done with R statistical software version 3.6.2 (packages rms, 202 ggplot2, ggradar, nCOV2019, recharts). All reported probability values were 203 two-tailed and the criterion for significance was set at P=0.05. Univariate statistics 204 and distribution were assessed and continuous variables were presented as means and 205 standard deviations or median and inter-quartile ranges (IQR). Categorical variables 206 were expressed as frequency and percentage. The crude prevalence of depressive 207 symptoms was displayed from January 1 to February 9. The chi-square test was used 208 for categorical variables. Mann-Whitney U tests were applied to continuous variables 209 with a non-normal distribution. We investigated the association between the number 210 of changes per day (COVID-19 confirmed cases, suspect cases or death cases) and 211 EPDS scores using ordinary least squares linear regression models. We also 212 investigated the risk for depression (EPDS≥10) using logistic regression models. The 213 analyses were adjusted for potential confounders such as age, BMI, education levels, 214 occupation, annual household income, parity, investigation site, family support, 215 per-capita living area, the only child in her family, pregnancy complications, and 216 exercise level. Ordinal logistic regression model was used for a response variable with 217 each EPDS items and with explanatory factors. Further model assumptions were 218 assessed by plotting model residuals and evaluating R 2 /sum of squared residuals. 219 We undertook a subgroup analysis to investigate whether the increased risk of 220 depressive symptoms was explained by associated COVID-19 epidemic declaration, 221 using radar plot and attributable risk proportion and 95% confident intervals. To 222 further examine risk factors, we examined COVID-19 related factors, baseline 223 variables and pregnancy complications using logistic regression. The parameters 224 included COVID-19 epidemic declaration, education levels, occupation, annual 225 household income, family support, per-capita living area, the only child in her family, 226

FIGREF5.text: characteristics. A total of 4124 pregnant women were included in the 234 analysis, of which 2839 were investigated before January 21, 2020 (group 1). The 235 distribution of demographic characteristics, including geographical region, was 236 similar between the two study groups

FIGREF6.text: , awareness of COVID-19 epidemic significantly increased the 243 prevalence of depressive symptoms (EPDS≥10) (aRR=1.20, 95% CI: 1.04, 1.40, 244 P=0.01) and the risk of self-harm thoughts (aRR=2.85, 95% CI: 1.70, 8.85, P=0.005). 245 Number of suspected and confirmed COVID-19 cases increased rapidly after the 246 human-to-human transmission was first reported on January 20, 2020 (Figure 1a-b).247Between January 20 to February 9, a stable increase in the prevalence of depressive248 symptoms (EPDS≥10) was found as the number of suspect and confirmed cases 249 increased. Overall, the prevalence of depressive symptoms was 26.0% in group 1 and 250 29.6% in group 2. Subgroup analysis showed that the frequency of high EPDS scores 251 between January 20 to February 9 was 34.2% (n = 81, EPDS≥10) and 13.9% (n = 33, EPDS≥13) with the largest increase in symptoms after February 5. To further analyze 253 the adverse effect of COVID-19 epidemic, standard linear regression models were 254 used to examine the association between depressive symptoms and the number of new 255 infections reported per day. Both number of new confirmed infections (β=0.09, per 256 increase 1000 cases, P=0.003) and suspected infections (β=0.06，per 1000 cases 257 increase, P=0.004) per day were positively correlated with the prevalence of 258 depressive symptoms (Figure 1c-e). A linear positive association was also noted 259 between EPDS scores and the number of new confirmed infections per day (β=0.09, 260 per increase 1000 cases, P=0.04). A significant positive correlation was found 261 between number of new deaths per day and the prevalence of depression (β=0.05, per 262 10 cases increase, P=0.001), and correlation with EPDS scores (β=0.08, per 10 cases 263 increase, P=0.008). 264 Risk factors for Depressive Symptoms. FIGREF7.text: subgroup analysis was conducted to explore risk factors specifically associated 271 with depressive symptoms during COVID-19 outbreak from January 20 to February 9 Figure 2). Contribution of sociodemographic factors to the increased prevalence 273 during the outbreak was shown in Figure 2b. Women at higher risk for depressive 274 symptoms include those with a middle annual household income and low levels of 275 physical exercise. Interestingly, pregnant women who were primiparous, younger than 276 35 years old, with a per capita area of ≥ 20m 2 and of pregestational BMI ≤ 18.5 277 appeared to be more vulnerable to develop depressive symptoms during the 278 COVID-19 outbreak as were those who were employed full-time.

FIGREF9.text: Consistent with previous meta-analyses, we confirmed several risk factors for 303 depressive symptoms in the whole sample such as low social economic status,304    insufficient social support and poor health behaviours including a lack of physical 305 activity.17,18  Additionally, maternal only-child status, a common phenomenon in306    women of reproductive age due to China's one-child policy, was found an 307 independent risk factor for depression. In the face of the COVID-19 outbreak and the 308 knowledge of human-to-human transmission, subgroup analyses found pregnant 309 women who were <35 years old, underweight, primiparous, middle-income, working 310 full-time, and residing in a per capita living area of ≥20 m 2 were now more likely to 311 experience depressive symptoms. These women are not typically at high risk for 312 perinatal mental illness as we identified in the whole studied pregnant women, and 313 this may help explain the increased rates found in this study after the pivotal January 314 20, 2020 date. Concern for the economic fallout and increased unemployment caused 315 by the COVID-19 crisis may explain why middle-class women were at increased 316 risk.19  Conversely, having to leave home to work full-time may have increased 317 concern for infection and vertical transmission and thus increased risk for depression318    and anxiety. A lack of physical exercises was continuously associated with depressive319 symptoms independent of the epidemic. Meta-analytic results suggest physical 320 activity has a protective effect on mental health in young adults. Even small amounts 321 of exercise (e.g., walking <150 minutes per week) decreases the incidence of 322 depressive episodes. 20 These findings suggest one potentially modifiable factor for the 323 onset of depression is physical activity and that programs to support exercise across 324 the perinatal period are warranted. In an infectious disease pandemic, exercises in 325 isolation or at home may help to decrease the depressive symptoms of pregnant 326 women. For example., home based exercises, such as walking extra steps around the 327 same rooms on the flat, or exercising on stairs every few hours could be included as 328 an essential part of the self-isolation or protection guidelines. 21 329 Clinical implications 330 Our present data revealed an increase in the proportion of women with thoughts 331 of self-harm, which could potentially result in death and injury indirectly caused by 332 this COVID-19 outbreak. The interventions for perinatal mental health should be a 333 priority during any public-wide epidemic. Although mental health issues have been 334 acknowledged during pandemics and a guideline of psychological crisis intervention 335 specifically for COVID-19 has been published by the National Health Commission of 336 China, perinatal women have not been highlighted in this guideline as a vulnerable 337 population. 22 Screening for perinatal depression and anxiety has been internationally 338 recommended and should be a priority during an international public health crisis. 339 Under the circumstances of population-based social distancing and isolation, 340 psychological hotlines and online counseling would be a safe and feasible strategy to 341 manage perinatal mental illness. With the limited medical resources, women who 342 have previously experienced perinatal depression could be recruited as trained 343 volunteers to provide telephone-based peer support that has been shown to have studies addressing the screening and management of 347 perinatal mental health via virtual care are warranted. From the SARS experience we 348 learned that the stressful impact of an infectious disease is qualitatively distinct in two 349 ways from the stress of other disasters. The first is that potential exposure to a 350 contagion which brings social isolation. Interpersonal isolation in an infectious disease 351 outbreak results in: (1) the required use of personal protective equipment and physical 352 distancing to control the spread of disease; (2) the strong tendency for those who are 353 potentially exposed to cope with significant stress; and (3) the tendency of others to 354 fear, avoid, and stigmatize those who have been potentially exposed. 24,25 The second 355 distinctive characteristic of an infectious outbreak is that pregnant women have 356 heightened fear for their unborn fetus's safety. Given the mental health consequences 357 of a dramatic life-threatening outbreak for pregnant women, organizational and 358 personal resilience strategies should be investigated and may include evidence-based 359 approachs to effective risk communication and the provision of psychological first 360 aid. 26 Importantly, clear communication with regular and accurate updates about the 361 outbreak should be provided as preventive strategy for mental well-being. Emotional 362 and behavioural responses are part of an adaptive response to extraordinary stress and 363 psychotherapy techniques such as those based on stress-adaptation may be effective. 364 In any public health emergency, feelings of fear, uncertainty, and stigmatisation are 365 common and may act as help-seeking barriers to appropriate mental health 366 interventions. 367 Strengths and limitations 368 This study is the first to report the mental health response of pregnant women during 369 COVID-19 outbreak in China. An ongoing multi-center cross-sectional study to 370 examine the mental health of pregnancy women provided a unique opportunity to 371 compare the prevalence of depression before and after the national declaration of an 372 epidemic. While this innovative study has numerous strengths, it did not include 373 pregnant women from Wuhan, Hubei province. The severe situation and strict 374 quarantine measures in Wuhan due to the outbreak of COVID-19 prevented us from 375 conducting a further study. Another limitation is the assessment of depressive and 376 anxiety symptoms, which relied on a self-reported measure. Although the EPDS and 377 the anxiety subscale is an internationally recommended screening measure and it has 378 been used in numerous studies with Chinese women, it does not provide summary, this study examined the mental health of the pregnant women during the 383 COVID-19 outbreak. Our findings indicate a clinically significant increase in the 384 prevalence of depressive and anxiety symptoms after the declaration of 385 human-to-human transmission and an increased threat of the COVID-19 epidemic.
